scenario:
The S&P 500 has declined by about 10% since the start of 2025, causing portfolio losses. To reduce volatility, investors can consider dividend stocks, which provide a tangible return in the form of income. Vanguard offers several exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that focus on dividend stocks, including the Vanguard Utilities ETF (VPU), Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF (VYM), and Vanguard Real Estate ETF (VNQ).

The Vanguard Real Estate ETF focuses on real estate investment trusts (REITs), which own income-generating real estate and pay dividends. REITs have historically been less volatile than the broader stock market, with a beta of less than the S&P 500. The Vanguard Real Estate ETF has a dividend yield of around 3.5%, higher than the S&P 500's 1.4% yield.

The Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF focuses on companies with high-yielding dividends, providing a higher base return. Its top holdings include Broadcom and ExxonMobil, which have excellent records of growing their dividends. The Vanguard Utilities ETF owns companies that distribute electricity, water, or gas, generating stable cash flow and a higher yielding dividend of 2.9%.

Duke Energy, a top holding in the Vanguard Utilities ETF, has paid dividends for 99 straight years and has raised its payment for the past 18 years in a row. The company invests heavily in supporting the growing demand for electricity in the regions it serves, indicating continued dividend growth.
